body:
Yes, but you have to override the default table. For example:

``` ruby
  show do
    attributes_table do
      row('Renamed'){ |r| r.username }
    end
  end
```

@seanlinsley - glad that this ability exists, but it's frustrating that the syntax is different when customizing labels on the index v. the form v. the show page.  

It also took me a while to find this, you should add to the docs on the show page info :)

@edatrix why is there a difference?

``` ruby
    attributes_table do
      row('Renamed'){ |r| r.username }
    end

    attributes_table do
      row 'Renamed' do |r|
        r.username
      end
    end
```

That is just a other ruby code style.

@timoschilling that's not what I meant, what i mean is that here (in the attributes table) you have to override the default with ruby.  When adjusting labels for the index or on the form, it's easy to just pass in a label.  It would be convenient if it were consistent across all ActiveAdmin elements, preferably by just passing the string.

examples:

``` ruby
index do
    column :category
    column "This is the name of the column", :column_label
    column "Another Label", :another_label
end
```

``` ruby
form do |f|
    f.input :column_label, :label => "This is the name of the column"
end
```
@edatrix someware is already a discussion about that, but I can't find it at the moment.

row("label_row){table.field}

I think it's correct, at least work fine for me.

Is this feature available now? Because it would be quite useful, and not including it makes for some confusing inconsistency with the implementation of attributes in general. Inputs have it, columns have it, filters have it, is there a reason for rows to not have it?
Yeah as @edatrix said, there should be consistency doing this simple customization in all AA or at least in `show`, `index` and `form` page.

issue.title: Specify label for attributes_table row

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
I want ability to specify label for row in attrubtes_table like for index column headers. E.g.:

``` ruby
show do
  attributes_table do
    row :name
    row "Student", :user
  end
end
```

As I understand from code it's impossible right now

issue.title: Unify specifying label in show -> attributes_table

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
Up to now, the only way to specify a label in a row in attributes_table was by using the first argument. The data was then taken from executing a block:
```
attributes_table do
  row 'Renamed' do |r|
    r.username
  end
end
```

This pull request allows for syntax:
```
attributes_table do
  row 'Renamed', :username
end
```

The same syntax is used by index:
```
index do
    column 'Renamed', :username
end
```

Closes #3359, closes #167

body:
+1 for this feature

Meanwhile, in newer versions  of Ruby, I'm using
```
row 'Timestamp', &:created_at
```
but would still like to see consistency here

> +1 for this feature
> 
> Meanwhile, in newer versions of Ruby, I'm using
> 
> ```
> row 'Timestamp', &:created_at
> ```
> 
> but would still like to see consistency here
Just want to highlight that this trick does not work for `attributes_table_for`

Is there any way to make the label in uppercase in the show page? Actually I want to do something like this 
```
row("GST Registered") {
  r.gst_registered
}
```
But it doesn't work, it's only making the words start with capital.

> Is there any way to make the label in uppercase in the show page? Actually I want to do something like this
> 
> ```
> row("GST Registered") {
>   r.gst_registered
> }
> ```
> 
> But it doesn't work, it's only making the words start with capital.

You need to pass a block, try something like:

```ruby
row('GST Registered') { |r| r.gst_registered }
```

or

```ruby
row 'GST Registered' &:gst_registered
```
@cristi I tried that too. But it isn't working.
